title: prince harry meghan markle royals celebs
story: If pushed, I might hazard a guess that Prince William’s brother Harry was in the mix somewhere, but other than that . . .  nada, zilch, nowt.And yet they were all made public at the time. So why all the cloak-and-dagger secrecy surrounding the godparents to Meghan and Harry’s son Prince Archie He’s seventh in line to the throne and, quite frankly,the majority of us had been standing next to the font, we’d probably struggle to name rumoured godparent Charlie van Straubenzee the following day.I have just typed it and I’ve forgotten it already. So why risk losing the already fragile goodwill of the public by treating them asthey’re tiresome selfie-hunters  It’s like those celebrities who put a “no photos” hand up when you haven’t even got your camera out.Or the ones who tell journalists the most anodyne fact about themselves, then add: “But don’t quote me on that.” As .It reminds me of the time when I found myself as a “plus one” at the wedding of a Z-list celebrity who had flogged his nuptials to Hello! magazine.Post-ceremony, the guests were left hanging around as the happy couple did their contracted, painfully proooootracted photoshoot, so I sauntered off to the shade of the nearest tree to make a phone call. Within seconds, the groom appeared at my side and hissed: “If you’re filing copy on this, I will have you removed.”I was simply calling home to say goodnight to my five-year-old. Harry and Meghan’s disproportionate defensiveness over their son’s christening smacks of a similar celebrity narcissism.The reality, one fears, is that this whole “privacy please” charade is yet another example where the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are blurring the lines between “royal” and “celebrity”. Being the latter means you pay for everything yourself.But being royal means you have -hour police protection funded by us, transport and living expenses funded by us, a £.million refurbishment of your house funded by us and your child is deemed important enough to be baptised by the Archbishop of Canterbury.And inyou perform the occasional public duty and follow the royal traditions that have sustained the Monarchy for hundreds of years.One of those traditions being the inclusion of godparent names in the royal register. So omitting them from the official court circularis bordering on the non-constitutional.And when the tourist magnet of tradition, pomp and ceremony is pretty much all the Royal Family has left as a bargaining chip with the already hard-pressed taxpayers who fund them, that’s a bold, some might say reckless, move.A recent poll asked, “do the Sussexes have the right to keep godparents’ names secret”, and  per cent said “yes”,  per cent “no”, and  per cent “don’t know”.Don’t know, or don’t care  And therein lies the rub. The impeccably dutul Queen is hugely respected but, after she dies, what then The public may well feel that Harry, Meghan et al can have all the privacy they desire. But in , they must give up all the royal trappings and pay their own bills.TELLY regulator Ofcom has received  complaints from people concerned about the “mental health” of Love Island contestant Amy Hart after she was dumped by “half-boyfriend”Curtis Pritchard.Sigh. With everything going on in the world that’s truly worthy of complaint, how depressing that the type of “boy dumps girl”scenario that’s played out daily in homes, bars, schools, parks and cafes the world over is deemed to be a matter worthy of investigation.Yes, Amy was “heartbroken” and had a good sob. But anxiety is a “mental health” issue. So is depression, bi polar disorder, schizophrenia, etc etc.Feeling upset because someone you met three weeks ago has placed you back in the “friend zone” is not the same thing.Equally, Amy – who has now voluntarily left the villa – willingly signed up for a reality show where she knew full well that relationships are constantly tested and the ensuing responses filmed  .A bit of heartbreak is all part of le’s rich pattern, isn’t it  You feel awful for a few hours, days or weeks , then tell yourself that he she “isn’t worth it”, change out of your pyjamas and move on.Worryingly, Amy said Curtis had robbed her of her future. No Amy – you are your future, and anyone who comes along to share it with you is merely a bonus.Work on loving yourself and before long it will be: “Curtis, who ”THE number of pensioners wanting to flat-share has soared , per cent in the past decade.If The Bloke ever trips and falls under a busI will hopefully be one of them.My friends and I often muse that, one day, we’ll sell our current homes and pool resources to buy a large property that we’d name “Symbiosis House”.There, we would watch Escape To The Chateau, play Scrabble and backgammon, drink buckets of rose and look after each other by bringing our own set of skills to the late le party – be it cookery, gardening, administration or entertainment.We would have company when we needed it, but our own room to retreat to when we didn’t.And best of all, none of us would ever feel lonely.MICHAEL GOVE and David Cameron have reportedly ended their three- year feud with drinks at an exclusive private members’ club in London.Whether their once-friendly wives feel the same way remains to be seen.AS a patron of Help For Heroes, I can’t stress highly enough how important it is to support our Forces veterans.When we needed them, they put their lives on the line for us.And now they are the ones in need of help, this country must look after them. Who could argue against that Yet despite the ongoing physical and hidden injuriesall too many of them suffer, successive governments have failed to come up with a cohesive plan that actually delivers the right care for their needs.So The Sun’s campaign for a small, dedicated “Office Of Veterans’ Affairs” in the Cabinet Office is a vitally important one that could make a vast dference to the lives of, among so many others, soldiers such as Ben Parkinson, , who suffered le-changinginjuries in Afghanistan and now needs constant care. The next PM should put it at the top of his to-do list.JEREMY PAXMAN says he doesn’t miss presenting Newsnight because: “I spent  years listening to people talk b*****ks every night. That was enough.”At least he was paid to hear politicians etc wittering on. The rest of us have to pay for the, er, privilege in the form of the £. licence fee.“GOING in to town” was a big thing when I was in my late teens.We frequented the local pubs, spent hours in Cha Girl looking for the perfect jeans and gathered in cafes for gossipy chats over an exciting new drink called “cappuccino”.Now, according to high streets minister Jake Berry, middle-aged Brits like me are abandoning local shops because we’re either too busy working or engrossed in TV box sets.So he’s issued a plea for us to, “show the high street some love”.Hmmm. story: Shauna Fairley, , shoved the victim to the floor and kicked her during the dispute about a male interest.The victim, Sarah Parker, who had been to a wedding that day, was rushed to hospital following the attack in Sunderland city centre.She received seven stitches to the wound and was left scarred.Ms Parker even changed her hairstyle to conceal the markings on her face, which her children repeatedly question.Fairley, of Sunderland, admitted assault and was spared prison after the judge accepted she was genuinely sorry and had acted totally out of character.At Newcastle Crown Court, Judge Robert Spragg sentenced her to six months imprisonment, suspended for  months, with rehabilitation requirements and £ compensation order.The judge told her: CCTV shows the kick taking place, when she is on the ground. title: seumas milne jennie formby labour aides bbc panorama
story: But who are Seumas Milne and Jennie Formby, the aides featured in the documentary  Heres what you need to know.Seumas Milne is Mr Corbyns communications chief and a formerjournalist who worked for the paper for more than  years.He is the author of the book The Enemy Within: The Secret War Against the Miners, focusing on the strikes during the mid-s.He was appointed the Labour Partys Executive Director of Strategy and Communications in October , under new Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn, initially on leave from .In January  he left the paper to work for the party permanently.He reportedly told officials the party was muddling up political disputes with racism and must review processes.It was claimed in a new documentary that Mr Milne laughed when advised by a long-serving party official about what Mr Corbyn should do to tackle anti-Semitism in the party.Jennie Formby is a British trade unionist and politician.She is the current General Secretary of the Labour Party, having succeeded Iain McNicol in April .She joined Labours NEC - National Executive Committee- the partys ruling body in .Previously, she was political director and south-east England regional secretary for Unite the Union.She reportedly attempted to interfere in who sat on a  examining a high-profile case.It is claimed in a new documentary that officials brought in by Ms Formby overruled disciplinary decisions and downgraded punishments to a slap on the wristUp to a dozen ex-Labour staff are said to have spoken to the BBC about how the party processes complaints, and whether senior staff intervened in cases.The explosive documentary will reveal how some of Mr Corbyn’s closest aides are said to have intervened to stop anti-Semites being kicked out and laughed off calls to tackle the crisis.Eight ex-Labour staffers broke restrictive gagging orders to lay bare the sheer scale of racism in the party.They told BBC Panorama how the party was hit by a flood of cases of Jew-baiting racism after Mr Corbyn became leader in .The partys storm over how it deals with anti-Semitism allegations has now been swirling for more than three years - and the Labour boss has been repeatedly accused of not taking the problem seriously enough.Labour have furiously denied the allegations and written to the director general of the BBC accusing the corporation of bias.A Labour spokesman said the party is absolutely committed to tackling anti-Semitism.In response to the Panorama programme, a Labour Party spokesperson said: “The Labour Party at all levels is implacably opposed to anti-Semitism and is determined to root out this social cancer from our movement and society. Labour stands in solidarity with Jewish people and is fully committed to the support, defence and celebration of the Jewish community and its organisations.“Jeremy Corbyn has a long and principled record of solidarity with the Palestinian people and it is  to claim that he has associated with extremist groups. Jeremy Corbyn has proactively addressed anti-Semitism within the Party in direct communications to the Party membership, in articles, speeches, videos and interviews.“The Leader’s Office did not intervene. story: Yes, it should have happened long ago, of course.Wednesday night saw a series of devastating revelations about anti-Semitism in the Labour Party from the BBC’s brilliant Panorama programme. And the direct but illicit involvement of Magic Grandpa himself in what were meant to be independent investigations.Even before that came out, three peers resigned from the party because of the vast numbers of Jew-haters in Labour.One of those to quit is Lord Triesman, a top bloke. He was once a very capable boss of the Football Association. He resigned saying Labour was “instit- utionally anti-Semitic”.And he added that “the experience of le in the party has become sickening”.Even Corbyn’s closest allies among Labour MPs have had enough of him. Diane Abbott, for example. And the Shadow Chancellor, the sinister John McDonnell.Other Labour MPs are sick of being bullied by the convocation of weird Maoists, Trots and Leninists who surround Corbyn. People such as Seumas Milne and Andrew Murray .All of this has helped Labour sink to an astonishing all-time low of  per cent in the polls — at a time when we’ve had the worst Conservative Government in memory. Or at least since John Major was in charge.And now the party has finally turned its back on the people it was set up to support, the working class.It has decided to back the idea of a second referendum on Brexit, junking its previous decision to “respect the vote”.Hundreds of thousands of Labour voters in the North of England will be lost to the party as a consequence, possibly for ever.So the knives are out for Grandpa and I don’t see him lasting much longer. It is now a case of WHEN he goes, not IF he goes. But even when he goes, what can a new leader do with this rabble Don’t forget, the party is controlled entirely by the activists. And those are the , middle-class, liberal lefties and perpetual adolescents who joined the party en masse for three quid to ensure Corbyn was elected leader.They have nothing in common with Labour’s old voter base, the working class. They are opposed to Brexit. They are in favour of Hamas, Venezuela and Cuba. They support identity politics, with its endless hierarchy of victimhood groups.So the likelihood, then, is that a new leader will also come from the juvenile far Left.There are some great Labour MPs who would make excellent leaders of the party — Caroline Flint, for example, or Jon Cruddas. But do they stand a chance any more, seeing how the party is It’s more likely we’ll end up with John McDonnell, an unrepentant Marxist who thought IRA bombers should be given honours by the British government. Or one of his and Corbyn’s proteges.It could well be the end of the party as a viable political force full-stop.Ah well. Time to say goodbye to Jezza. It was fun while it lasted, mate. In a really grim kind of way.GRIM viewing, wasn’t it  That leadership debate.Smirky Hunt trying to convince everyone he has charisma and stands a chance of winning. And our next Prime Minister, Bozo, incapable of giving a straight answer to anything.Can you imagine asking Boris the time “Well, ha ha, I think that’s a very interesting question. And some people may be prepared to tell you it’s eleven o’clock, or perhaps five to five. But I’m not going to do that. No. Not me. That’s for others to say.“I will tell you, beyond all doubt, that it is definitely not seven o’clock, and that’s the important thing, the thing voters care about. And that’s why I think I should be your Prime Minister. Because I will never tell the electorate it is seven o’clock when it isn’t. And, indeed, even when it is.“Does that answer your question, Julie ”GOOD – he’s gone. Sir Kim Darroch, our ambassador to the US.Caught out when leaked messages revealed he thinks Donald Trump is “inept” and the White House dysal.He had to go, evenhe has become a darling of the liberal establishment here for hating Trump.Here’s a suggestion. How about we get as his replacement someone who understands Trump and Trump’s appeal to US voters DO you really think Boris Johnson is going to get us out of the European Union  Properly, I mean, much as we voted for If so, pass the hallucinogens. I could do with getting out of my head too.My guess is we will leave in part, with a deal slightly weaker than the dog’s breakfast Theresa May put before us. And don’t be too surprised by a general election pretty soon. That will cheer us all up.Never have so many people been let down by their leaders. You can read about how Brexit was betrayed in my new book, The Great Betrayal, out next week.It’s a sorry story and it should make you angry. Mind you, it’s also quite funny,you have a warped sense of humour.THIS is Geronimo the alpaca. Take a good look at him because he’s not going to be around much longer.The Government has decided he must be slaughtered because, according to a possibly flawed report, he carries a strain of bovine tuberculosis. His owner, Helen Macdonald, is utterly distraught.The killing of Geronimo, and the wholesale slaughter of our badgers, has been forced on the Government by the farmers. They have way too much power.They create sterile landscapes on vast subsidies.It’s time for all this to stop. For our sake, as well as Geronimo’s.HAVE we ever had a member of the Royal Family who was smugger, more full of herself, more truly bloody irritating, than Meghan OK, King John was a bit of a t***er . . . but things were dferent in the th century. And more recently there’s been Fergie, I suppose.She had a few airs and graces and, like her ex-husband Andrew, was a bit of a . But at least she wasn’t a hypocrite.Meghan is insufferably woke – forever bleating about social-justice “ishoos” but happy to swan around in a private jet and have us pay millions for her cottage in Windsor.Now she’s decided she doesn’t like people taking pics of her when she’s on another freebie to Wimbledon.Get real, love, before you alienate the entire British public . . . instead of just chippy little monkeys like me.Or: “We had fizzy pop delivered.”More pertinently, “I have six teeth left,” or: “I remember hating Leeds United even before Don Revie arrived.”But that’s ten words and thus inadmissible.I SEE that Nicki Minaj has cancelled her concert in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.Everyone told her it’s a foul country where they don’t treat women especially well.But she seemed determined to push on.My worry is thatNicki dressed on stage the way she usually dresses on stage, she’d be on permanent display in Saudi, with her head on top of a pole. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: veterans save thousands discounts
story: The Defence Discount Service gives former and serving Forces personnel savings at nearly , businesses. But nine out of ten of Britain’s .million veterans don’t know about it.So The Sun has teamed up with the Ministry of Defence-backed ­initiative as part of our vital Never Forget Them campaign.We want all veterans to get a better deal when shopping or paying for services — including meals out, travel and even holidays — not just the , who have signed up.And we are calling on more businesses — of any size — to swell the ranks of the , firms offering money off.It comes after The Sun this week demanded our next Prime Minister back our three-part Veterans’ Pledge:Julia Cooper, , landlady of The Don bar, a hub for many veterans, in Stockton-on-Tees, Co Durham, said: “I can’t thank The Sun enough for standing up for former servicemen and women.“Many of the men who come here served in Northern Ireland and they live in fear of being arrested and charged for serving their country.”Key to the Defence Discount Service scheme is the Defence Privilege Card, which veterans can use in stores and at businesses large and small and get up to a third off. Discounts can be found online and via an app.George Rogerson, , who served seven years in the Gloucestershire Regiment, including three tours in Northern Ireland, hailed the scheme as “a recognition of service to the country”.The former Lance Corporal, who was mentioned in dispatches after saving the le of his wounded­ commander under sniper fire in Belfast, has used the discount card since .George, from Chirk, Clwyd, said: “Veterans like me did our bit for your country and I use my card virtually every week and save money. I don’t regard it as charity.When I show my card and get discount, it’s like a recognition of my service to the country and a ‘thank you’. I’ve lost count of the hundreds of pounds I have saved over the years.”Another veteran saved £ on his phone alone from EE. Yet virtually none of the veterans The Sun spoke to yesterday in The Don had heard of the scheme.Among them was Pete Gaines, , of Sedgefield, who served  years with the Royal Artillery. Pete, who has not worked since a heart attack at , vowed: “I am going to sign up and save myself money.”Or visit Google Play or the Apple App Store and download the Defence Discount Service app.The app allows members to search for discounts in their local area as well as browse discounts on the move.It is FREE to join butyou want the Defence Privilege card, which you can carry in your wallet, there is an admin fee of £., which lasts for five years.Tony Walls, , from Thornaby on Tees, was another in The Don keen to join in.An ex Corporal who served  years with the Pioneer Corps, leaving in , he thought the scheme was only for those still serving.He said: “I had heard of this scheme but I didn’t think it was for me. I am certainly going to check it out.”The scheme means veterans and serving Armed Forces can enjoy discounts ranging from ten per cent off to, in some cases,  per cent discount on thousands of everyday items.It is not just giants such as Starbucks, National Express, Jet holidays, Enterprise Rent A Car, Halfords and KFC that take part. Thousands of small businesses are also on the list of , firms — such as bridal shop Willoughby  Wolf, in Marlborough, Wilts.Victoria and Spencer Wolf only opened the shop last September but signed up to the DDS scheme because former Warrant Officer Spencer, , serv­ed  years in the Royal Signals.Victoria, , said: “We benefitted from the scheme with discounts on things like cinema tickets and when we became business owners we wanted to pass that benefit on to other veterans.”Already they have given discounts totalling around £ to serving soldiers or former servicemen and women.Victoria added: “The first thing I ask our brides-to-be is do they have a brother, husband, father or close ­relative who has served or is serving  I point them in the right direction. Spencer spent over  years serving this country. Being able to pass on some benefit is really important to us.”The Sun is urging more companies to sign up. And the message is already getting through.Last night food giant Iceland confirmed it is considering giving discounts to veterans.And Cadbury World in Birmingham said it offers a  per cent discount for the military, who can bring up to six people with them on a booking. They just need a form of military ID or be a member of the Defence Discount Service.We will pass them to the Defence Discount Service so your firm can help those who served and boost your business by gaining loyal new customers.The more companies that get involved the more we can help our ­veterans.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hms queen elizabeth third leak
story: The £bn carrier - the biggest warship ever built by the Royal Navy - suffered a flood after an internal high pressure water pipe burst.Big Liz is now entering a planned maintenance phase early while engineers investigate what caused the fault.She was due in later this week, but sailed back into Portsmouth on Tuesday night.The Royal Navy tried to play down the leak, calling it “minor.”But sources on board said the flood was “serious” and affected multiple compartments.The fault is feared to be a burst pipe in a highly pressurised salt water internal sprinkler system – designed to put out fires.Insiders claimed the leak had damaged some bulkheads and doors – and at points was waist deep.One source, said: “The official line is that a minor flood forced her back to Portsmouth but in fact it was a fairly serious flood.“A total of eight compartments were flooded and this is not minor at all.”Reports claimed some crew were at risk of drowning in the flood – but that was strenuously denied by the Royal Navy who insisted there was “no threat to le” during the incident.Insiders said the fault was quickly isolated and all the flood water had been pumped out of the ship.This is the third time the new carrier – the nation’s most potent symbol of maritime strength - has suffered leaks.The Sun revealed in  the new warship had a leaking stern seal - part of the propeller shaft - that insiders called “signicant.”Then weeks later an internal sprinkler system failed sending gallons of waters gushing from the ship’s ceilings to douse a non-existent fire.Despite insisting the leak was minor, officials admitted an investigation had to be carried out whenever something “usual happened” to discoverthere is a more “fundamental error.”A Royal Navy spokesman, said: “Following a minor issue with an internal system on HMS Queen Elizabeth, the ship’s company were required to remove a small volume of water from the ship.“An investigation into the cause is underway.”The spokesman said at no point was there “damage or breach” to the ship’s hull.They said the earlyof HMS Queen Elizabeth was a precautionary measure.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: As soon as President Trump announced he wouldn’t be speaking to our man in Washington, there regrettably wasn’t anything he could realistically do. title: iran standoff royal navy oil tanker
story: Irans elite Revolutionary Guard tried to take control of the vessel as it passed through the Strait of Hormuz - sparking a tense standoff in the Persian Gulf, US officials revealed.But HMS Montrose quickly trained its mm deck guns on the enemy boats and warned them off, they added.It has since been confirmed by Sky News that the warship also deployed its Wildcat helicopter to circle the Iranian boats in a bid to scare them off.The British Heritage tanker was being escorted through the flashpoint region by the Montrose amid feverish tensions between Iran and the West.But the Navy frigate rallied into action when the rival boats approached the oil tanker and demanded it change course into Iranian waters.According to the anonymous officials, the Montrose came up from the rear of the tanker and aimed its weapons at the Iranians - before issuing a verbal warning to get away.One of the officials said: The Royal Navy HMS Montrose, which was also there, pointed it guns at the boats and warned them over radio, at which point they dispersed.The other added: It was harassment and an attempt to interfere with the passage.A US aircraft was flying overhead at the time and recorded footage of the standoff, the officials said.The attempted capture comes just days after British Royal Marines seized an Iranian crude oil supertanker off Gibraltar.Commandos dramatically detained the Grace  tanker over suspicions it was carrying oil to its ally Syria in violation of EU sanctions last week.Iran later issued a chilling threat of retaliation for last Thursdays daring raid.President Hassan Rouhani warned on Wednesday that the UK will suffer consequences for its actions.He said: I tell the British that they are the initiator of insecurity and you will understand its consequences later.And Irans Major General Mohammad Bagheri warned the seizure of the Grace  will not go unanswered.A deputy commander of Irans elite Revolutionary Guards today said that Britain and the United States will regret detaining the oil tanker.Now an action that does not need ability but some stupidity has been carried out by them, Rear Admiral Ali Fadavi, a deputy Guards commander, said, according to Tasnim news agency.The American government, and also England, should not have taken actionthey had made the smallest calculation, he said.We had rented this ship and we carried the cargo. Their action was very silly and they will certainly regret it. Our reciprocal action will be announced.Confirming the Montrose standoff yesterday, a Government spokesperson urged Iran to de-escalate the situation in the region. The Government spokesman said: Contrary to international law, three Iranian vessels attempted to impede the passage of a commercial vessel, British Heritage, through the Strait of Hormuz.HMS Montrose was forced to position herself between the Iranian vessels and British Heritage and issue verbal warnings to the Iranian vessels, which then turned away.We are concerned by this action and continue to urge the Iranian authorities to de-escalate the situation in the region.Iran later accused weak Britain of lying about the incident in a bid to inflame tensions in the region.Tehrans foreign minister Mohammad Jawad Zar appeared to deny the Islamic Republics boats were being confrontational.He said: They make a claim to create a tension that these claims are not worthwhile, and raised many claims.Mr Zar also said England was attempting to cover their weaknesswhile blasting America for engaging in economic terrorism referring to the sanctions imposed on Tehran by Washington.Initial reports from the US said that five Iranian vessels had harassed the tanker.Responding to the reports, US Central Command spokesman Cpt Bill Urban said: Threats to international freedom of navigation require an international solution.The world economy depends on the free flow of commerce, and it is incumbent on all nations to protect and preserve this linchpin of global prosperity.UK defence officials have previously confirmed that the Montrose had been deployed to the region to perform a maritime security role.A spokesman for Theresa May said the Prime Minister is concerned about the incident in the Gulf and called for a deescalation.The British Heritage ship - operated by BP - earlier made an “abrupt” u-turn and ed to the safety of Saudi Arabia’s coastline on Sunday.It had been heading to Iraq’s Basrah terminal when satellite trackers showed it changing course.Tensions continue to rise between Iran and the West after the Islamic Republic last week announced it was upping its uranium enrichment programme.Tehran plans to increase its production beyond the limits imposed by the  Iran Nuclear Deal - which the US walked away from earlier this year.US President Donald Trump said the deal had been too soft - but it was still supported by other western backers including the UK.Following Irans announcement, Trump vowed on Wednesday that sanctions on Iran would soon be increased, substantially!Last month, President Trump called off a planned airstrike on Iranian military targets at the last minute in retaliation for the shooting down of an unmanned US drone.Iran had earlier been blamed for a series of devastating sea mine attacks on US-linked oil tankers in the Strait of Hormuz.

title: four bed house incredible secret bar inside
story: The £k property in trendy Hackney comes with a private garden and a bespoke fitted kitchen - and its own private PUB.Stunning pictures reveal the house is decked out with a magnicent wooden bar - complete with four stools and a stained-glass ceiling.The RightMove listing drily states that the house requires modernisation.The Victorian decor extends through four bedrooms, a bathroom, a kitchen, and a double rear extension.It says: This four bedroom Victorian family home is located on a peaceful tree-lined street.The property does require modernisation throughout but offers great potential.There is a double storey rear extension which maximises the living space and accommodation comprises two bedroom on the lower level which could potentially be reception rooms.There is a fitted kitchen diner and family bathroom to the ground floor.To the first floor there are two double bedrooms and a spacious room to the rear which is currently being used as a bar this has the potential to be changed into a further double bedroom and bathroom.Externally there is a private rear garden.

title: m25 queues motorway pile up accident
story: Junctions - clockwise have been closed since am this morning as photos show a white lorry slammed into the motorways side barriers and stretched across several lanes.The driver of the articulated lorry was raced to hospital by air ambulance with le threatening injuries, cops said.Occupants of the other vehicles are not injured.Dramatic images of the scene show a London cab with its doors open and lights on metres away from the jackkned lorry.Cops said a London taxi and red Citreon were the two other vehicles in the smash near Wisley interchange at J this morning.Surrey Police tweeted at .am: M nine to  from Highways England likely that closure will remain for six for eight hours due to fuel spillage.Drivers were left jammed in  miles of queues each side of the incident.Congestion was stretched right back past junction  on the clockwise carriageway and as far as junction  heading anticlockwise.Cops said the motorway was likely to be closed until mid-afternoon while emergency services are at the scene and a large diesel spill is cleared.A further collision blocked part of the M at South Mimms, affecting traffic between junctions  and  for Potters Bar in Hertfordshire.Diverted traffic should follow the yellow hollow triangle symbol, via the A, A, A and A through Tadworth, Epsom and Tolworth.There is a height limit of ’  at the Tolworth railway bridge on the A.Officers are appealing for anyone who witnessed the collision, or who may have dash cam footage of the driving of any of the vehicles before the collision, to get in touch.Anyone with information should contact Surrey Police by calling  and quoting the reference number PR P.

title: pilot turns blue emergency landing
story: The plane allegedly rolled in the air as terried holidaymakers watched the panicked plane crew try to help the unwell pilot - who they thought may have had a heart attack.A passenger on board the flight recounts: The plane suddenly lurched, a man emerged from the cockpit and fell in the aisle.“Later I realised he was the captain.“Stewards began to search for a doctor in the cabin, panic was growing.“The face of the collapsed pilot went blue then a young woman ran to him and started first aid.The plane started descending quickly - people were crying, as I was.“The landing was not soft, as it was reported but the second pilot did well, all the passengers applauded.The co-pilot of the Montenegro Airlines flight reportedly informed air traffic control of the situation and a decision was taken to land the plane as soon as possible in Kaluga  miles, southwest of Moscow.Tourists on board said the plane with  passengers and five crew “rolled” in the air during the drama.Another passenger, Nastya, said: “The captain was unwell, at first, the plane suddenly moved to one side, or even rolled a bit.“Then he came out of the cockpit and just collapsed and there was no doctor on board.“The flight attendants were worried and panicking.She said: “I feared for lives of my family on board the plane.”Nastya added: “Sometimes I cry during take off or landing, but I never cried as strongly as today.”Other accounts said the pilot had felt sick and went to the toilet - but fainted on the floor after leaving the cockpit, in full sight of alarmed passengers.The co-pilot touched down in Kaluga - “but the landing was not so smooth”, said one frightened passenger.The pilot recovered only when the plane came to a stop on the ground, reportedly saying I will have a rest for about  minutes and we will fly again!’”However, ambulances rushed to the scene and the captain was immediately taken to hospital.A tourist on board called Tatiana Smirnova said a young female passenger, aged , had provided first aid for the collapsed pilot.“She did well, but there was no basic medication in the first aid kit on board for somereason”, she said.Russian authorities said no-one was hurt during the emergency and Montenegro Airlines reported that the safety of passengers and crew was not at risk due to this incident.Passengers from flight YM were taken by bus to Moscow’s Domodedovo Airport where the aircraft had been scheduled to land.The captain reportedly fainted due to the low tonicity of his muscles, with doctors denying he had suffered a heart attack.

title: drink driver ploughs party brixton
story: Mustafa Esmail, , jumped into a rented VW Golf and sent party-goers flying outside the Red Onion shisha bar in Brixton, South London.One victim, chef Fuad Ahmed, , suffered multiple fractures to his arm, a broken ankle, a fractured nose and his eye popped out of its socket.Others were left with horrendous injuries that are likely to resonate down the years, the Old Bailey heard.Esmail has now been caged for  years with an extended license period of four additional years after admitting five charges of causing grievous bodily harm with intent.The court was told Esmail had been barred from entering the bar on December  as there was a private party so he started swinging punches at late night revellers.Sozzled Esmail then got behind the wheel of an Ubeeqo rental car and deliberately rammed five people who were stood on the pavement outside the bar at mph.The court heard Mr Ahmed had now lost his livelihood working as a chef and a mechanic because of the horric injuries to his arm, ankle and eye.He cant walk without crutches and is dependent on painkillers, which has affected his mental health.The chef said: In short, this person, the defendant, has ruined my le.Sentencing, Judge John Dodd, QC, said: You drove the car mercilessly and quite deliberately. There is, in my view, something particularly cowardly about the using of a car as a weapon.This was a shocking and terrying event, fuelled by at least drink.You were turned away because the venue was hosting a private party, you fought with the door staff before beating a retreat.Your parting shot was, however, to say that you would be back. With you at the wheel, that car plainly became a lethal weapon.Esmail, who has a previous conviction for attacking his mum, also admitted battering Aaron Thomson with a bottle outside a Brighton nightclub after selling him a wrap of fake cocaine.The thug also punched him repeatedly in the savage attack in  outside Coalition, which left the victim with injuries to his neck, head and face.He was give nine months concurrent for the attack after admitting a single count actual bodily harm against Mr Thomson.The prosecution offered no evidence on five counts of attempted murder in respect of the driving incident.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: naples underworld tattooed mafia drama photographer
story: Photographer Sam Gregg said he wanted to delve past the city’s rough image and show the human side to le in the city which regularly tops the European crime index.Famed for its beautul coastal landscapes surrounded by the glamour of the Amalfi Coast, Naples is a sprawling urban settlement steeped in a rich Italian history.However, the mafia-style syndicate the Camorra, depicted in Sky-produced drama Gomorrah, still holds power in the city.In January, , a ten-year-old girl was shot in the foot during a mafia raid on a group of migrants.Graffiti and tattoos featured heavily in the photographer’s work along with topless Nepalese sun-worshippers.Most of the picture subjects are inhabitants of the Spanish Quarter and Rione Sanità, two of the town’s most vibrant areas.Sam said: “It is a documentation of the spirit and vibrancy of the people who live in these areas, who remain steadfast even in the face of adversity.”The project was inspired by writer Johann Wolfgang Von Goe’s phrase “See Naples and die” which referred to the beauty of the city.However, the wording has taken on a new meaning because of its high rates of crime.The photographer continued: “Although Naples regularly tops the European crime index rankings, the situation in the city’s central areas is steadily improving.“Unfortunately the media consistently plays a role in glamorising and propagating Naples’ negative image.“I am not discrediting this issue as it is a real and pressing matter, I am merely highlighting through my photography that the people affected are tangible human beings before they’re political units.”

title: daniel sturridge dog lucky luccie
story: The Liverpool striker was seen carrying his beloved Pomeranian outside his £m mansion in Los Angeles.This comes after Sturridge was blasted by the rapper who claims he found the adorable mutt for only giving him £.LA cops said the dog had been found safe and well after people contacted the footy ace and he identied it as his.Twitter user Killa Fame, who described himself as a “Los Angeles trap music artist”, posted a video along with a series of pictures of a similar-looking dog.He tweeted Sturridge directly, asking “Is this Lucci ” and telling the athlete “Man I got him” in response to one of his desperate social media pleas.After handing the dog back, he tweeted: Found @DanielSturridge dog Lucci by me and my nephew... no sizable reward .. so dishonest lies.He then accused Sturridge of not paying up because the dog was found by a black man.Sturridge did not publicly reply to the tweets, although in a tweet of his own just hours earlier he urged anyone with information to contact him with a private message on Instagram.It comes after Sturridge posted an emotional Instagram video announcing that the dog had been found.He said: Good morning everyone. Just want to say were waking up to good news that Lucci has officially been brought home. Myself and a few friends went to south LA last night to pick him up.We were told by somebody in La basically that they had him, they were in south LA on the east side so we drove down there at about :pm last night and picked him up.Absolutely delighted. Cant believe it. Just want to say a big thank you to everyone on social media who supported us and raised awareness to the case of what was going on and Im so thankful to all of the fans around the world, all the influencers, celebrates, general people and media.Killa Fame, who lives in an Isuzu Trooper, told The Sun last night his nephew had found the dog on the street.He claimed the ex-England striker did not even say thanks when he picked him up. He added: “He spent less than five minutes here. He earns thousands per week – yet he only gave a homeless family .”Sun Online has contacted Sturridge’s representatives for comment.The footie star revealed his heartache this week with a series of Instagram videos from his Los Angeles house which was burgled.Detectives arrived at the property on Tuesday afternoon as they started gathering evidence in the hunt for the kidnappers.They took fingerprints from the broken door but Sturridge himself has taken matters into his own hands.He shared his address, CCTV footage of the kidnappers entering the mansion as well as pictures of his dog, which is worth up to £,. The striker revealed that a few bags had been stolen by the burglars.But the loss of the favourite pet was what hit him hardest and he pleaded with the dognappers to come backthey wanted to make money.He said: “£, straight up. Twenty g’s, thirty g’s, whatever.“Bring my dog back to this house, I’m moving out of this b**** anyway, I don’t give a s*** about this place.“Bring the dog back to this address, I’ll be moving out tomorrow or the next day. I want my dog back and I’ll pay whatever.“You ain’t going to get more than that anyway. Andyou are let me know and Ill pay more than them. I’ll pay more than them.”

title: shocking cctv armed machete raid family home kent
story: The two fearsome-looking men were caught in menacing CCTV images before they smashed their way in the home of Chris and Emily Bushby.Chris and Emily, along with their four children, live in the upmarket Knockholt near Sevenoaks, Kent.The raid happened in broad daylight on Monday, not long after the mum and kids had left the house to get a punctured tyre fixed.Detectives are now hunting the suspects.The two men were wearing tracksuits and stalked the house before smashing their way in, where they stole a number of items before fleeing.One can be seen armed with a large machete.Police are investigating the burglary in the pretty village of Knockholt, near Sevenoaks, Kent, and Emily has posted photographs of the raiders in a bid to track them down.The -year-old mum said: Luckily I was meant to be on the school run but had had a puncture so me and kids were out, so grateful for that.My son was the first person to run into the house and he said he thought somebody had made a mess of a room.I was confused and when I walked in I realised what had happened. It was shocking.I called the police straight away - before I even went into the rest of the house.I should really have been in the house myself. I only missed them by a few minutes. Usually, I would have been in.I couldnt believe it.In the raid, the men took some of the familys passports and sentimental jewellery.Besides the robbery itself, Emily was shocked at the weapon the men were carrying, making the intrusion a dferent ball game.She added: Why would somebody feel the need to arm themselves with a machete Thats what I keep thinking - and what would have happened to meI had been there.The traumatic ordeal has shocked the whole Bushby family, and Emily claims that one of her daughters has been having nightmares about it.Her husband, Chris Bushby, , told BBC South East: One of the guys crouched down and throws all his might to smash the glass of the French doors.At that same time they looked around and the guy with the machete is there looking about.Then they disappeared inside. They were really determined. Its scary seeing them do it - especially with a machete as well.They were called at .pm on Monday  July  to a break-in at an address.A spokesperson said: It is reported two men, one of whom was carrying what has been described as a machete, entered the unoccupied property by breaking through a rear door and stole a quantity of jewellery.Both men were wearing gloves and balaclavas. One of them is described as being stocky and was wearing a dark tracksuit top, dark tracksuit bottoms with a white stripe down each leg and black trainers.The second man is described as having a slim build and was wearing a light grey hooded tracksuit top with dark grey stripes on the arms and shoulders, light grey tracksuit bottoms and black trainers.Investigators have been carrying out a number of enquiries including forensic examination at the scene and reviewing any potential CCTV opportunities in the area.

title: greece storm brit dad dive tree
story: Ollie Pitham, , was on holiday in Ikos Olivia resort, with his we and two young sons, age  and , when he was forced to e out the way of a ft tree as it fell towards his apartment.The ferocious storms ripped through a tourist region in Greece last night, killing seven holidaymakers including a toddler and an eight-year-old boy.At least  others were injured after gale-force winds, rain and freak hail storms struck the Halkidiki peninsula in northern Greece.Ollie, from London, describes how he and another family hed travelled with were walking their children around the resort when the weather suddenly changed.He said: “We were on holiday with our friends and their two boys and Id decided to go for a walk to get the kids to sleep while the wives had a drink.“The weather had been great, reaching C but it suddenly changed in a matter of minutes.“The lightning started first and within five minutes the rain and winds hit and people were shutting the bars and restaurants.“We were told by staff to get back to our rooms so we ran as quickly as we could.“The kids were crying and everyone was in a real panic.“It was so surreal and everyone just went crazy.”After getting his family safely back to their room, Ollie ventured into their private garden to take videos of the terrying storm.Ollie, who owns an interior design business, said: “I wanted to get some footage of the storm but heard a snapping sound.“If I hadn’t been paying attention it could have been a lot worse, it could have killed me.“It fell sideways and broke all the fencing - butit had fallen slightly closer to the building it could have done a lot of damage.Ollie said his boys were terried during the ordeal and the family were forced to pull the kids beds away from the windows in case another tree fell during the night.Thankfully all family members escaped the storm unharmed and Ollie says the hotel staff provided excellent support.Ollie, who flew out with his family last Saturday, said: “We were very lucky.“A lot of other trees fell too but the one in our garden was the biggest.“Staff came this morning to remove the debris.”Dramatic footage shows strong winds sweeping through the region, which is popular with tourists in the summer.Other British holidaymakers were trapped in their hotels, buildings were damaged and cars were overturned in the carnage.A -year-old man and a boy, aged two, who are believed to be from Russia, died after a tree fell on their vehicle, according to the Greek Reporter.Two elderly Czech nationals were killed when strong winds swept away their travel trailer in Halkidiki, police said.A woman and an eight-year-old boy, both from Romania, were killed after a roof collapsed on a restaurant in Nea Plagia and a seventh body was found at sea.Athansios Kaltsas, director of the Nea Moudania Medical Centre, said: It is the first time in my -year career that I have lived through something like this. It was so abrupt, and so sudden.Officials have declared a state of emergency in Halkidiki and Greeces newly appointed citizens protection minister is due to visit this morning.Such severe weather is unusual in Greece, where summers are typically hot and dry.Meteorologist Klearxos Marousakis described conditions as extremely unusual for this time of year.

title: charity helped secure 13m extra
story: AdvertorialCharity has helped secure £.m in extra benefits for poor families - could you be entitled to more money Talking Money offers free specialist advice and ongoing support when people need it mostShareByDave Masters:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL AdvertorialNick Leaman from Talking Money helps Kathleen and Emlyn sort out their finances"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLike many people in their s, Kathleen and Emlyn Doughty are not comfortable with computers. So when it came to applying for disability benefit, they struggled in a world of websites and online forms. That was when Nick Leaman came to the rescue. The advisor with Bristol-based financial education charity Talking Money came to their house, and took care of everything. “Nick is a hero to us,” says Emlyn, . “He comes over and immediately puts you at ease. He knows exactly what to say and is so knowledgeable. “I am from the old school, and to understand something I need it in my hand. I don’t even know how to switch a computer on. But everything is online these days. I can’t even print out a form.  We are just relieved that Nick came over and explained everything to us and help us out.” Nick’s help was invaluable for the couple, who are both disabled and struggle to get out, and were falling behind on their rent. Nick’s work with Talking Money involves helping people who find themselves victims of fraud or who may be struggling with debts and don’t know where to turn. And the financially qualied advisor helps people access the benefits they are entitled to, with free specialist advice and ongoing support when they need it most. Over the last year the charity has received more than , enquiries and helped more than , people with advice and casework.They have also secured £.m for vulnerable low-income households by identying and applying for additional benefits they’re entitled to, including appealing negative decisions around housing benefit, sickness and disability benefits and Universal Credit .The majority of Nick’s work is through face to face consultations in Bristol and the surrounding area.  And he says many of his older clients struggle with the internet. “Older people are missing out because they can’t navigate online. I do feel compassion for them. They suffer from a lack of knowledge and access to information. Many of the best deals are online too so they miss out in that way too.” But the majority of people Nick helps are of working age. “It used to be the case that they had racked up huge credit card debts. But it has changed. The issues are now that they are struggling to pay rent and utility bills because they just don’t have the funds. Often they are in work, but they don’t get given enough hours or just not being paid enough. Or it might be the case they are facing financial crises because of unexpected le changes, such as relationship break-up, redundancy and bereavement. “It is also scary how much fraud is out there and how many people get scammed. Fraudsters are getting increasingly confident and can be so convincing. I had one lady who received a text saying she owed thousands to HMRC. It was a con, but she almost fell for it and was going to pay even though she was barely able to afford her rent. The problem is thatyou are desperate you are more likely to fall for scams like this because you just don’t think sensibly.” Despite the enormous demand on him, Nick loves his work. “It can be stressful but it is also really fulfilling because you are here to help people.  Evenyou can improve their lives just a little, that can make a huge dference to them. For others it can be le-changing.” For more Stories of Local Pride, click here

title: only john major can save
story: NewsopinionOnly John Major can save the Tories now. Thats how bad things have gotIs it a bird  Is it a plane  No, its Supeaman!ShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JUL Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email In these distrusting times, the best way to judge people is by what they DONaposT tell you. You will not have heard anyone say: Jeremy Hunt  Brilliant! No-one has made the effort to describe what a great bloke Boris Johnson appears to be. And nobody, but nobody, has rhapsodised about what a great idea Brexit is for ages. While they spin, bluster and refuse to tell us what they wonapost do, itaposs the subjects theyaposre dancing around we all ought to be paying attention to. Subject : Sovereignty of Parliament The Brexit twats said we had to Brexit so Parliament had more power over our laws. Before we have even Brexited, they have decided Parliament has too much power, and should therefore be shut down so laws can be enacted without it. Subject : Control of our borders We were told we must Brexit to to control the flow of trade and people across our borders. The Brexit twats are now furiously denying there will be any controls at all on the one border we share with the EU. Subject : Letaposs spend £m on the NHS insteadThis works out to £.bn a year, but because the number is entirely wrong itaposs actually £.bn. Either way, the NHS funding gap is about £bn a year and growing.Youaposll note they didnapost say the EU costs us each p a day, letaposs spend it on the NHS instead. Subject : Brave new trade deals Secondhand bassoons, jumpers from the Faroe Isles, and selling the NHS to Donald Trump. Let us say no more about it. Subject : The will of the people This one is still occasionally mentioned, although in increasingly-quieter voices. Because the will of the people has, for the best part of two years, been solidly Remain. Leave constituencies have voted in Remain campaigners, there were more Remain than Leave MEPs elected last month, and everyone whoaposs not a blind, bonkers Tory can see Brexit has gone the way of the Norwegian blue. Today, what theyaposre not telling you is that John Major was once considered the most pathetic, grey, boring, rudderless, bastard-beset, pea maniac Prime Minister weaposve ever had. And he is now the Tory Partyaposs best hope.While Vanilla bitchslaps Marmite on the TV hustings, a man once ridiculed by the entire nation for being a middle-aged Clark Kent without the superpowers has snapped his power pants back on and declared heaposll wrestle either one of them to their political death.Stop staring at our potential PMs for a moment, asking yourselves how it is possible these two unappetisers are the best the natural party of government can offer. Marvel instead that the voice of sanity now looks and sounds a lot like an aged Mr Bean. Sir Johnaposs reputation has changed since he left Downing Street. We have since been exposed to claims that he shared bathwater, among other things, with Edwina Currie.Once upon a time that was one of the more shocking political sex scandals. It was news that made people stop eating their dinner with their fork halfway to the mouth, their eyes widening as they said: Wha  But those were more innocent times.  Major was the last Tory PM to defeat the anti-European wingnuts in his own party. In  he signed the Maastricht Treaty, the deal which helped to form the modern European Union.The fact he won that fight is the reason a more youthful Nigel Farage left the Conservative Party. It is why, a year later, UKIP was founded by an economist. And a little after that, a faction led by Farage ousted that leader on the grounds he was too intellectual.To be fair, then, this is very much Majoraposs fight. If you criticise David Cameron for running away, mild-mannered Major should be praised at least for coming back.It must be coincidence that Mad Cow Disease is coming too.   We all know proroguing Parliament, and making laws only a minority want, is undemocratic. But by threatening a judicial review, Major has exposed the fact itaposs un-Tory, too.No patriot should seek to destroy civil institutions that work just fine. No democrat should hold the people to an opinion they no longer hold. And no Tory should f*** business. Prostitutes, pigs, secretaries - these are all, sadly, expected. Perhaps even Edwina, in extremis. But Brexit means destroying Parliamentary sovereignty, promising a total lack of border control, ignoring the will of the people and wasting billions of pounds on schemes we currently enjoy with % cashback.   Boris Johnson will tell you to be optimistic about all of that. Jeremy Hunt says it must happen. Both of them are wrong. Because John Major, for all his flaws, are all the things they are not.He is a former Prime Minister. He is an election-winner. He defenestrated Margaret Thatcher. He saw off the Eurosceptics. He survived not only ridicule but the worldaposs worst Currie.And he s bearing the Brexit kryptonite - facts, democracy, the rule of law, and good old British sovereignty which says we are ruled by the Parliament, the courts, and the governments we choose. Not emotion, wish-fulfilment, or a government imposed upon us by the insane. But Supeaman is not alone. There are millions of us, from all parties, classes, and walks of le. And you donapost need X-ray vision to see that Brexit is up to no good.

title: union reports two government departments
story: NewsUnion reports two government departments to police over strike breakingThe PCS has claimed that the FCO and Business Department used agency workers when low paid workers from their own departments were on strikeShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsThe workers were on strike over pay and recognition "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Public and Commercial Services union has written to politan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick urging her to investigate allegations that two government departments illegally used agency workers to break strikes.  The union has alleged that during two strikes this year - at the Foreign Office and the Department of Business Energy and Industrial Strategy - the departmentaposs brought in agency staff to cover the roles of striking low paid workers.    The departments are accused of using the sht workers to cover the stoppages by contracted out workers who were striking against their pay. Workers at BEIS employed by Aramark and ISS have been on strike several times since December in a campaign for the London Living Wage. And Interserve staff at the FCO have been on strike over a lack of union recognition and several redundancies.    The union claim that a company provided people to cover striking BEIS workers from  to  June.  They also said two other companies covered roles of striking FCO workers on the , ,  and  May and from  to  June. Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long Bailey MP said the development was hugely worrying.“The alleged intention of strike breaking within Government departments is hugely worrying. Not least because UK regulation provides that this is prohibited.What is more worrying however, is that one of the departments at the centre of this controversy is responsible for the enforcement of workers’ rights.“There must now be an urgent investigation and I stand in full solidarity and support with those workers who are fighting for a living wage and decent conditions.”The union claim that under regulation  of the Conduct of Employment Agencies and Employment Business Regulations of , it is illegal for any business to provide agency workers to cover strike actions. General Secretary Mark Serwotka has written to Tory leadership contender Jeremy Hunt , Met Police Chief Cressida Dick, BEIS permeant secretary Alex Chisholm and BEIS Minister Greg Clark, urging that these serious breaches be investigated and that ministers intervene to resolve these industrial disputes.

title: jilted bride sells unworn dress
story: NewsJilted bride sells unworn dress after fiancé dumped her for wedding planner palDonna Bettiss, from Horsham, West Sussex, was supposed to marry James Routledge but he decided to end things weeks before the big dayShareCommentsByHelen Le Caplain:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsDonna Bettiss and James Routledge have split weeks before they were due to marry "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A jilted bride is selling her designer dress after her fiancé cancelled their £, ceremony to hitch up with their wedding planner pal. Sheaposs now listed her £, Sophia Tolli aposMonteapos sleeveless tulle and sequin gown on Facebook for £ as it remains a constant reminder of what had happened.Their pal Paige Hannington, , had offered wedding advice over cocktails after she tied the knot some months before. But during a work trip recently, James and Paige drunkenly confessed they both werenapost happy in their relationships. James called off his wedding and began dating Paige weeks later.    Donna, from Horsham, West Sussex, said: I really liked Paige, she helped me so much [with the wedding] so I feel completely betrayed. I was distraught that someone I knew and trusted and was discussing such an important time in my le with, could do that to me. I even saw them on a night out but I just left them to it. The day I let James go was the day I realised he no longer loved me and I couldnapost force someone to love me or stay with me, that would be selfish. “The dress has been at my uncle’s house until recently, but now it’s hanging in my wardrobe. “I can’t keep it, there are too many bad memories. I desperately need it goneI want to move forward and rebuild my le. “Having it hanging there is a constant reminder of what happened. “I originally listed it for £, on eBay but there was no interest in the dress, so then I listed it for £ on Facebook and wrote what my partner had done. “Since I wrote that I’ve received lots of positive messages.”  The advert reads: “Open to offers, never worn. Wedding was cancelled due to [redacted] fiancé. “Desperately need gone, cost me £, had it a year and it’s a constant reminder. “Sophia Tolli dress size  never altered.” Donna and James met in March  at a nightclub in Horsham, West Sussex, and the following day Donna searched for him on social media and sent him a message. Six months later loved-up Donna moved in with James who then proposed and presented her with a diamond cluster engagement ring. Donna said: “I instantly fell for him and we soon spent every single day together. After a couple of months he told me how in love with me he was. “We were both really, really happy and so madly in love - head over heels - I wanted to spend the rest of my le with him.”  The pair were happily engaged and bought a two-bed end-of-terrace house where they lived together with Donna’s cat Sammie. Bride-to-be Donna excitedly booked four-star Nutfield Priory in Redhill, Surrey, as the April  wedding venue and picked her dream wedding gown, bridesmaid dresses and busied herself making hand-crafted decorations. As Donna immersed herself in wedding planning, newly-married Paige regularly offered her wedding planning advice over cocktails. Donna said: “The whole time from June up until November was wedding planning. “Paige and I would meet up for a cocktail and she would give me stuff for my wedding. “She even gave me her spreadsheets which were a massive help. “We also did a lot of over text and Facebook and she would tag me in dferent things. In September Donna picked up her designer wedding dress and said the gown, which hugged her curves, made her feel like royalty. Donna said: “When I went to pick up the dress with my mum and tried it on I said ‘mum I feel like a princess’. “I felt so pretty and elegant and it struck me that I really was getting married and wanted to spend the rest of my le with him. “Mum was crying and other people in the shop were welling up too.”  However two months later, in November , Donna was stunned when James delivered the bombshell news that he didn’t love her anymore and the wedding was off. Donna said: “When he told me he didn’t love me anymore and that we weren’t going ahead with the wedding I was broken. “I collapsed to the floor and cried my eyes out. “I went for a walk to get away from the house to process what had happened - the James I had loved had gone. “When I came back to the house, he told me there was nothing to talk about. I had no option but to leave. “I rang a friend who told me to pack a bag and go to her house straight away. I was up all night crying my eyes out. Devastated Donna fled to her friend’s house as she processed what happened. Donna said: I didnapost go to work, I didn’t eat, sleep or talk. I didn’t do anything. My friend said she’d never seen anything like it. “I just went completely numb and sat in the same spot for four days.” Newly-single Donna eventually moved back in with her parents and lost three stone in weight due to the stress of the break up and not eating properly. Since the break-up Donna has slowly started to rebuild her le and met her current partner -year-old data analyst Nick Pashley four months ago. Donna said: “It’s a really beautul dress and will make someone’s day. “The a-line dress draws you in at the waist and then it flares out and covers everything up, it makes you look like you have the tiniest waist.” James said: I paid for pretty much everything for the wedding. Pension scam Thousands of women have been penalised by the change in the retirement age. Now they are being punished yet again for taking time out of work to raise a family or look after an elderly relative. A report says women have £, less in pension pots than men.  The shortfall is compounded by the fact they often earn less than their male counterparts and are more likely to be in part-time jobs. Auto-enrolment is helping bridge the gap, but more must be done to help women remain in work. That means providing better childcare and social care. Joy all family

Liz Travis, , was on holiday in Halkidiki with her family when they got caught up in the extreme weather in Greece which has seen six people killed and more than  injured. The grandma described her family crouching on the floor of a taxi with their heads down, guarding her two year-old grandson as the storm lashed outside. She described fearing the car would turn over as it rocked, with tree branches hitting the vehicle on their way back to Halkidiki after visiting a nearby village. Liz said they were shaking, thought they would die, and said she began praying in fear despite not being religious. The sales negotiator from Bishopstoke claims they even saw a car appearing to slip over the edge of a clf and admitted she woke up from a nightmare this morning following the traumatic scenes they saw. Liz and her family went on an evening excursion to nearby village Afytos, about  minutes from their hotel. As there were seven of them, they had arranged for two taxis to pick them up at pm last night. Liz was in the car with her husband James Travis, , her -year-old daughter Sian Yates and grandson Finley Yates, two. In the taxi behind were Sianaposs husband Jamie Yates and his parents. As soon as they got in the cars, thunder and lightening hit and all the lights went out in Afytos amid a power cut. Within two minutes on the road, golf ball size hail stones began falling and the taxi driver desperately searched for a safe space to hide.  Liz told: The taxi driver said aposIaposve got to pull over, there are stones coming out of the skyapos. She said aposIaposve got to find a safe place to parkapos. In minutes there were golf balls of hell coming out of the sky hitting the car. We couldnapost see where we were going, cars were putting their hazards on. We were only going a few miles per hour as the taxi driver couldnapost see, she was crawling. We found a driveway and pulled into it - five minutes into the journey. The gates were swinging back and forth. The car was rocking and we thought we were going to turn over. Tree branches were hitting us, we could hear the sound of the water gushing. When they stopped in a driveway, Liz said they all sheltered on the floor of the car. She told: We were all crouching on the floor of the car. Describing the aftermath, Liz said the metal poles on umbrellas by the pool were bent in half, gazebos were blown over on the beach. title: neil armstrong describes moment stepped
story: NewsNeil Armstrong describes the moment he stepped on the moon for the first timeThe first man to step foot on the moons surface left a detailed account of what it was like, before he died in ShareCommentsByClare Fitzsimons:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsAstronaut Neil Armstrong, commander of Apollo  and the first person to walk on the moon "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn the second part of our series celebrating the Moon landing  years on, the late Neil Armstrong shares his memories of the mission – from setting foot on the lunar surface before fellow astronaut Buzz Aldrin to splashing down into the Pacic Ocean... We had landed. Getting down on to the Moon was less important but, to actually touch your boot into the sand was signicant. It took much longer to depressurise the cabin than we anticipated. When we got the cabin pressure down to a very low psi – it took ­something like two hundred pounds of pressure to open that up. So we had to wait until we got to a very low pressure dference between the inside of the door and the outside of the door before it would break free. When I first exited the Lunar Module out on to the porch, Buzz [Aldrin] turned on a circuit breaker powering the camera. I asked Houstonthey were getting a picture and they said yes, but it was upside down. I’m at the foot of the ladder. The surface appears to be very fine grained as you get close to it. It’s almost like a powder. The ground mass is very fine. I’m going to step off the Lunar Module now... “That’s one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.”  I didn’t think about what I was going to say until after landing. I didn’t have confidence in our ability to get down safely, so I didn’t bother thinking about it under after we had landed. Once on the surface and realising that the moment was at hand, fortunately I had hours to think about it. I thought, ‘Well, when I step off, it’s just going to be a little step’. But then I thought about all those , people that had given me the opportunity to make that step and thought, ‘It’s going to be a big something for all those folks and, indeed, a lot of others’. Even so, I have never thought that I picked a particularly enlightening statement. It was a very simple statement. Stepping on the Moon was special, but it was only instantaneous because there was work to do. There was a checklist of things we needed to get on with.    I was surprised by a number of things. I was surprised by the apparent closeness of the horizon. And I was surprised that there was no dust when you kicked your boot. Where you don’t have an atmosphere you don’t have any clouds of dust. It has a stark beauty of its own. It’s much like the high desert of the US. It’s dferent, but it’s pretty out here. You generally have the impression of being on a desert-like surface with rather light-coloured hues, yet when you look at the material in your hand you find it’s a charcoal grey. The optical properties on the moon are most peculiar. It’s a brilliant surface in that sunlight. It’s an interesting place to be. There was substantial discussion before the flight on what the flag should be. It was questioned as to whether it should be an American flag or a United Nations flag. I thought the flag should just be draped down, that it should fall down the flagpole like it would be on Earth.  It shouldn’t be made to stand out or put into any rigid framework, which it ultimately was. We had dficulty getting it into the surface. It ran into the sub-surface crust. Then they said there was a phone call for me, and it was the President of the United States who was speaking from his office from the White House. I didn’t know it was going to be the President. A very nice congratulatory message from the President on behalf of everyone who had been working on the project. And that was a very pleasant surprise. And again there was work to be done, so get back to the job. NASA officials limited our surface working time to two and three quarter hours on that first surface exploration to assure that we would not expire of hyperthermia. We were operating in a near perfect vacuum.  The temperature was well above  degrees Fahrenheit, with the local gravity only one sixth that of Earth. Because normal air conditioning is inadequate for lunar conditions, we were required to use cold water to cool the interior of our suits. There was just far too little time to do the iety of things that we would have liked to have done. There were rocks in the boulder field that were three to four feet in size, very likely pieces of the lunar bedrock. It would have been very interesting to go over and get some samples of those. It would have been nice from our point of view to have had more time to ourselves so that we could have gone out and looked around a little bit.  The ascent to the Colombia command module had a characteristic unlike any other portion of the flight. The rockets would fire and move the vehicle upward then they would shut off, and we would be pushed the other way, then they would kick in again. The whole thing was like a rocking chair through the entire ascent trajectory. It’s a pretty spectacular ride.Watch  Days: To The Moon And Back on BBC iPlayerConspiracy theory More than  million people around the world watched the live televised footage of Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walking on the Moon. Since then, NASA has brought back kg of Moon rock, while in  the NASA Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter found the footprints left behind. Yet a poll found that % of Americans think it was staged. Conspiracy theories began in  when American Bill Kaysing published a pamphlet entitled We Never Went to the Moon: America’s Thirty Billion Dollar Swindle. He argued that the Moon landing was staged in a studio. NASA and other experts have debunked the myths. But hoax stories continued, encouraged in popular culture.

title: blether whistler jimmy was refereeing amateur games at the age of 80
story: Kenneth Brannan said he enjoyed the “absolutely brilliant article about my cousin, John Gourlay, which was submitted by John’s pal from boyhood, Gerry Cavanagh .”He continued: “As a schoolboy, John, who is  months older than me, was a great footballing prospect, but, sadly, for whatever reason, he didn’t quite get that vital break.“He ended up, very successfully, taking up a dferent type of career altogether.“John’s late father, James Gourlay , was also a remarkable and,I may say so, a wonderful person.“My Uncle Jimmy was very well known in and around Dundee for many years as a political figure and an equally well-known football referee.“Sadly, he passed away in .“In fact, Uncle Jimmy may well have set a record as a referee because, believe it or not, he continued to referee amateur matches until after his th birthday.”Kenneth remembers playing in a match officiated by his uncle.He continued: “That occurred just once and that was over  years ago when my team Tay Centre played a Sunday league match at Fairmuir. Before the game had even started, the late Bob Higgins and I were named as our team’s two substitutes.“Bob was not a happy bunny that day and he confronted our team captain, and said: ‘Why are me and Kenny th and th men ’ The captain replied: ‘Because we only have  available!’“We allhad a good laugh about that and I got my chance and came on during the second half.“Not long before the end of the game, my Uncle Jimmy, in his capacity as referee, made a decision in favour of my team.“It was a decision to which one of our opponents took umbrage to and he started to swear at the referee, who, believe it or not, was % against any swearing by anyone at any time – not just on the pitch, but anywhere .“He said to the player: ‘I can’t stand anyone swearing, especially on a Sunday.
